posts.name: Aiden B
posts.cooked:
We have COTs swerve , smaller swerve , mini swerve , long swerve , and many others, but when is BIG swerve? Like 6in wheel swerve.

From my understanding, some teams used big or pneumatic wheels in 2016 to maneuver around and over obstacles. If the scary swerve obstacle terrain game were to happen, would the stock swerve survive without modification or an alternative big swerve?

link_counts.title: MK4n Swerve Module – Swerve Drive Specialties
MK4i Swerve Module – Swerve Drive Specialties

posts.cooked: I know our team along with many others worked with 3d printed wheels last year to build some suspension into the solidish aluminum swerve wheels. Those will work for most rough terrain but if it comes to large objects the floor height of bumpers start playing into it and i don’t know of anyone running a 6in wheel with swerve

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
We had a different take on “Swerve Stilts” in 2023.  We were able to lift the forks of our Mk4i modules by 1/2" to improve the wheel approach angle on the Charge Station.   I am pretty sure you could do the same thing to let you use a 5" wheel on a Mk4/i/n, although you might have to flip the motors out of the way.

5406 swerve stilts 421×750 88.5 KB

5406 swerve stilts 421×750 88.5 KB

5406 swerve stilts 421×750 88.5 KB

I would like to see some 5 or 6" wheel Swerve options, especially if we get sharp bumps on the field again

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
AidenBeau:

when is BIG swerve?

I actually asked Patrick that during DCMP this year. He said that it’s too niche for SDS to peruse, and even if there were a terrain game their production cycle would take to long to release one.

posts.cooked: First number in the DC part number is 2.5.

That was a very fun project!

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked: Hmm, none of the swerve manufacturers I have met seemed like billionaires…

I don’t think swerve has much use outside of competitive robotics. The conditions for swerve to be useful are:

Going sideways is helpful

Every second counts

Terrain is relatively flat

Swapping treads often is worth it (often in terms of how long you’ve driven your robot)

On top of that, swerve is much easier to utilize when you can do it field-oriented, which isn’t a thing when you don’t have a field.
